DIV1.P: AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN, AND BY THE OLD AMERICAN COMPANY, NEW-YORK, WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE.
BY THOMAS MORTON, Esq. AUTHOR OF COLUMBUS, ZORINSKI, WAY TO GET MARRIED, AND CHILDREN IN THE WOOD.
NEW-YORK: PRINTED AND SOLD BY R. WILSON, NO. 149, PEARL-STREET. 1798.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by T.W. Fitzgerald, Esq.—Spoken by Mr. Macready.
DIV1.L: WHEN invalids possess both faith and wealth,
They'll find a nostrum to restore their health;
A panacea advertis'd to cure
Each ill the human body can endure.
But our bold Author claims a nobler art,
And advertises to relieve—the heart
So many patients he expects to see,
That I'm appointed as his deputy.
Now, then, your mental maladies explain,
And I'll remove or mitigate the pain.
Does love or jealousy your peace molest,
Revenge inflame, ambition gnaw your breast?
For jealousy, a sovereign balm behold,—
The husband's certain cure, a pill of gold;
This dose, administer'd with prudent care,
Dispels at once the frailties of the fair;
Deprives the proctor of his crim.-con. ee,
And tunes the chord that jar'd to harmony.
Sould love torment some Romeo's heated brain,
Or agonize a Iuliet's breast with pain,
Let them my poent remedy apply,—
The maid shall cease to pine, the youth to sigh:
Gold shall restore each drooping lover's health,
And passion find a stitute in wealth.
But let not ill-tim'd ridicule degrade
What Heav'n, when well applied, a blessing made,
To foster merit, wheresoever found,
And with improvement cheer a country round;
To feed the hungry, and to clothe the poor,
And send the beggar happy from the door;
To mitigate the horrors of despair,
And make the family of want our care;
To succour genius, drooping in distress,
Making the business of our lives to bless.
When the rich man can such employment find,
We wish his purse as ample as his mind.
For one poor patient I've an anxious fear;
And you must be his kind physicians here.
Our Author has to-night so much at stake,
He finds his throbbing heart inclin'd to ache!
But should his Play a lib'ral audience please,
Your warm applause will set his heart at ease.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—A Farm Yard. House on one Side, a neat Flower Garden on the other. The Bells of a Team jingling.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANK
SP.P: WOYH! Whoh! Smiler. (Enters.) So Feyther be not come home from the Nabob's house yet. Eh! bean't that sister Jessy in her garden, busy among the poseys?—Sister Jessy!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter JESSY from the Garden, a watering pot in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Ah, Frank. so soon returned from Gloucester? have you sold the corn?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: And how did you like the town? you were never there before?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: Loike it—I doant know how I loik'd it, not I; zomehow coudnt zee the town for the housen: desperate zight of 'em, to be sure—But, Jessy, you who went to Lunnun Town to take in your learing, can tell me, be there as many houses in Lunnun?
A hundred times the number.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And do your 'squires there▪ like Sir Hubert Stanley and the Nabob here, keep fine coaches?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: Yes, Frank; there are some thousands round St. Jamess Gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: St. James's Geat! Dong it; it wou'd be wort a poor man's while to stand and open that geat—Pray you, where do that geat lead to?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: The road to preferment Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ecod, if your road to preferment be so cramm'd wi' your coaches and great folk no wonder a poor man be run down when he tries to get a bit.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You seem to be in terrible good spirits, Jessy.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: I have reason, Frank, I have just received a letter from my dear Edward, who has left London on business with his father, Mr. Rapid, and will be here to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I suppose it be a desperate long letter, and cruel sweet. Full of kisses and voluntines.—Nine sheets, I war∣rant.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Hardly nine words. The truth is, that Edward, tho' handsome, generous, and I hope sincere, is impatient, and hasty to a degree, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hasty! What then? When a man be on the road to do good, he can't go too fast, I say.—Beant that Feyther coming thro' Wheat Ash? He have been drinking and gamestring all good Sunday night wi' Nabob's sarvants, —how whitish and deadly bad he do luck. He us'd to be as comely and handsome as either of us, wasn't he now? Do you know, Jessy, at church yesterday, Sir Hubert looking round, as he always do, to see if his tenants be there, miss'd Feyther, and gave me such a desperate look, that I dropt prayer book out of my hand; and truly, when Feyther do go to church, I be always sham'd, he never knows where to find the collect—never—I'm sure it be not my fault, he be so full of prodigality—never son set Feyther better exam∣ple than I dos mine; what can I do more for 'un? it woudnt be becoming in me to leather Feyther, would it, Jessy?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Here he comes—I'll return to my garden—to con∣verse with him is to me dreadful; for while my breast rises with indignation at his conduct as a man, it sinks again in pity for the misfortunes of a parent.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Now, that's just like I—I feels as if I shou'd like to lick 'un and cry all the time—but what will be the end on't, Jessy?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Ruin, inevitable ruin (despondingly)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Well, dont thee be cast down—thee knows I be cruel kind to thee; at meals, I always gis thee the desperate nce bits, and if thy lover prove false hearted, or Feyther shou'd come to decay, I be a terrible strong lad, I'll work for thee fra sun-rise to down, and if any one offer to harm thee, I'll fight for thee till I die.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Thanks, my good lad; thanks, dear brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: As nice a bit of a sister that, as in our country round.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Farmer OATLAND dressed in a compound of rusticity and fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: (singing). Ba viamo tutti tra.—Dom it this be what I call loife! Have you sold the wheat?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: How much?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Two load.—Six and twenty pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: (yawning). Exactly the trifle I lost last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: Take it to the Nabob's gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I were going, Feyther, to the castle, to ge it to Sir Hubert's steward for rent.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: Rent, you bore! That for Sir Hubert (snapping his fingers). Ah! Nabob's sarvants be the tippy—Every thing be done by them so genteely.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ecod▪ you be done by them genteely enough! I be sure that house have brought the country round to ruina∣tion. Before this Nabob come here wi' all his money, and be doom'd to 'un, every thing were as peaceable and deceant as never was;—not a lawyer within ten miles; now there be three practizing in village; and what's ameast as bad, there be three doctors; and the farmers so consated, drive about in their chay carts, eat lump sugar every day, and g balls.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: To be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And what's the upshot? why that they jig it away to county jail.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: Tezez vous! Let me see—Great cassino be ten o' diamonds. Well, then, I play—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Play! ecod, if you go on so, you mun work tho'.
Next I mun take care of the speads.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No, Feyther, a spade mun take care o' you; by gol▪ here be Mr. Heartley, Sir Hubert's steward;—now doan't you be saucy to 'un, Feyther;—now do behave thy zelf —now that's a man, Feyther, do. clapping him on the back.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Good day, Farmer Oatland; how dost do, honest Frank?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Desperate pure, thank ye, fur.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Well, farmer, once more I have calld respecting your arrear of rent—Three hundred pound is a long sum.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Three hundred pound!

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: And unless it be immediately discharg'd, Sir Hubert is resolv'd to—

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: That for Sir Hubert—He shall have his rent—Frank, send your sister Jessy to the Nabobs, he'll let me have the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No! I won't—What business have sister at such a desperate prodigal place! Na, na, Ill go myzelf.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: You are in the right▪ honest Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Yes, sur▪ I always am.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat
SP.P: Ugh! You vulgar mongrel—Well, desire the Na∣bob's gentleman to desire the Nabob to let me have three hun∣dred pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: He won't gi' thee a brass farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: Sir Hubert shall have his money—Ha! ha! ha! my notion is▪ he wants it sad enough, ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Sirrah!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Don't you mind 'un, sur don't ye, he be's into∣sticated. Dong thee, beheave thyzelf (with sorrow and vexation.)

SP.SPEAKER: Oat
SP.P: Silence▪ you hound! and obey▪—Bon jour, Mr. Steward—Ill to bed— Pon honour, I must cut Champaigne, it makes me so narvous—Sir Hubert shall have his money, let that satisfy—Follow me, cur. Exit into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Sad doings, Frank. Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: FRANK shakes his head and follows OATLAND.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—A Room in the Nabobs House.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Good Mr. Bronze, have you been at Sir Hubert Stanleys?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen
SP.P: Is Charles Stanley arrived?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: No, ma'am; but he is hourly expected.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Do they say he is well—quite recovered?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze
SP.P:
I don't know ma'am —upon my soul.—I beg pardon, but really the Baronets house is horrid vulgar, compared to your uncle's, the Nabob's here; I peepd thro' my glass into an old hall, and beheld fifty paupers at dinner, such wretches, and the Baronet himself walking round the table to see them properly fed.— How damn'd low!—Ugh! I woud bet a rump and dozen our second table is more gen∣teelerer than Sir Huberts own—But I must away, for we
expect the rich Miss Vortex—I beg pardon; but your name and the Nabobs daughter being the same, we call her the rich▪ to distinguish—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen▪
SP.P: And you do wisely—No term of distinction could possibly be more significant or better understood by the world than that you have adopted.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Hope no offence, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: None, Bronze, go in—

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: The last man on earth to offend a fine woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: The rich Miss Vortex—most true.—But now dear Charles Stanley is returned, I claim the superior title of the happy. Oh! Charles, when we parted last at Spa, how great the contrast; thy animated form was prisond in the icy fetters of disease, thy pase and quiv'ring lip refus'd a last adieu;—but ah! a smile, that seem'd borrow'd from a seraph, who waited to bear thee up to Heaven, swore for thee everlasting love. That smile supported me in solitude— but to solitude I have now bid adieu: and to be near the lord of my heart, have again enter'd this house, the palace of ruin∣ous luxury and licentious madness:—but here comes its whim∣sical proprietor.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. VORTEX, with a paper in his hand, attended by black and white Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Sublime!—Oh the same of this speech will spread to Indostan. Eh!—don't I smell the pure air in this room? Oh! you villains, would you destroy me, throw about the perfumes. For legislative profundity, for fancy and decora∣tion—'tis a speech—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: What speech is it, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Ah! Ellen, why my maiden speech in Parlia∣ment.—It will alarm all Europe;—Ill speak it to you—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: No, my dear uncle, not just now.—I hear you've been ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh! very. A strange agitation at my heart and such a whizzing and spinning in my head—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: I hope you've had advice?—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P:
Oh, yes I've had them all —One physician told me it was caused by too brilliant and effervescent a genius;— the next said, it was the scurvy;—a third, it proceeded from not eating pepper to a melon; another had the impudence to hint it was only little qualms that agitated some gentlemen
who had made fortunes in India;—one recommended a s voyage—another a flannel night-cap;—one prescrib'd water, —the other brandy; but, however, they all agreed in this essential point, that I'm not to be contradicted, but have my way in every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: An extremely pleasant prescription, certainly. But under these circumstances do you hold it prudent, uncle, to become a parliamentary Orator? I believe a little gentle con∣tradiction is usual in that House.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I know it—but if you will hear my speech, you will see how I manage—I begin—"Sir—"

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Your daughter, sir, is arrived from town.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Thank you, cousin, for this relief.— Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Zounds! I'm not to be interrupted.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: She is here, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: My dear Nabob, uncommon glad to see you. Ah! Ellen; what, tired of seclusion and a cottage?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: I hope, cousin, I am welcome to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Certainly; you know we are uncommon glad to see any body in the country—but, my dear Nabob, you dont't inquire about the opening of our town-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Nabob.
SP.P: I was thinking of my speech.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: The most brilliant house-warming—uncom∣mon full, above a thousand people—every body there.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Pray, cousin, do you then visit every body?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Certainly, they must ask me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Must! I should imagine that wou'd depend on in∣clination.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P:
Inclination! Pshaw! I beg your pardon, but you are really uncommon ignorant, my dear. They must ask me, I tell you.—Now suppose a Duchess rash enough to shut me from her parties;—very well.—She names a night—I name the same, and give an entertainment greatly surpassing her's in splendor and profusion.—What is the consequence? —why, that her rooms are as deserted as an Ex-minister's levee▪ and mine crammd to suffocation with her Grace's most puissant and noble friends.—Ha! ha! my dear Ellen, the court of St. James's run after a good supper as eagerly as the Court of Aldermen.—Ha! ha! your being in this coun∣try,
Nabob, was thought quite charming.—A host not be∣ing at home to receive his guests is uncommon new and ele∣gant, isn't it.—Here we improve, my dear, on ancient hos∣pitality—those little memorandums, Nabob, will give you an idea of the sort of thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Vor.
SP.P: (Reads). "March"—Oh! that's a delightful month, when Nature produces nothing, and every thing is forced.—Let me see— "50 quarts of green peas at five gui∣neas a quart," — that was pretty well:—"500 peaches"— at what?—"a guinea each."—Oh! too cheap.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: 'Tis very true; but I assure you I tried every where to get them dearer, but cou'd not.

SP.SPEAKER: Vor.
SP.P: And I suppose the new white satin furniture was all spoil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Oh! entirely—and the pier glasses shivered to pieces so delightfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Vor.
SP.P: Well, I hope you had the whole account put in the papers?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Certainly, else what would have been the use of giving the fete? Then the company; such charming ec∣centricity, such characters out of character.—We had a no∣ble Peer bowing for custom to his shop, and an Alderman turning over the music leaves for the celebrated Soprano; an Orator's lady detailing her husband's three hours speech in Parliament, and the Orator himself describing how puppets are managed at the Fantoccini; we had grandmothers mak∣ing assignations with boys, and the children of Israel joining the host of Pharoah.—Oh! my dear Miss Vortex, why don't you partake in these charming scenes?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: My dear Miss Vortex, six suppers would annihilate my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Oh! true; I forgt your small fortune: but I don't think it much signifies, I swear people of fashion in town seem to do as well without money as with it. You might be successful at play—there are points to be learnt which certainly do not give you the worst of the game. Come, will you be my protege?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Excuse me, cousin. I dare say I ought to be co∣vered with blushes when I own a vulgar detestation of the character of a female gamester; and I must decline the honour of your ntroduction to the hat ton, till at least they have justice on their side.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: An uncommon odd girl, Nabob.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Heavens! to what state of bject degradation must fasonable society be reduced, when officers of police are as much by ladies in the purlis of St. James's, as they are by cut-purses in the of St. Giles's.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: For shame, Ellen, to censure your own sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Nor Madam, I am it's advocate—and in that sex's name protest an abhorrence of those woen who do not con∣sider any thing shameful but to be ashamed of anything—whose resemblance to nature and innocence exists but in their na∣kedness, and to whom honour is only known as a pledge at a gaming-table. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Did you ever hear, Nabob?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I did not hear a word she said—I was thinking of my speech.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: A pert, Gothic, low-bred creature! But her contemptible fortune suits uncommon well with her groelling ideas.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Don't you talk of her fortune, it always makes m poor ead worse. You know at the time I gave her fie thousand pounds in lieu of what I call'd her expectations. I had in my hands an . O dear! I'm afraid the doctor was right—ah! are certain East India —I wonder if giving her fifty thousand back again woud do my heart any good.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: What! my dear Nabob? I declare you quite shock me.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh conscience!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Conscience! he! he! a thing so uncommon vulgar, a thing so completely ; besides, you know very well it is absolutely impossible to exist under 20,000l. a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: That's very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Some people certainly do contrive to on with ten thousand, but how they do it is to ; th think of your intention of marrying me to the son of your great rival the Bronet; think of his borough.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Ah! very true.—Conscience avaunt; I have made a motion on matrimony to Sir Hubert.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: And young Stanley's arrival; Oh! what a sweet youth!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh! what a sweet borough interest! I'm glad your heart is interested.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Heart interested! Lud, how can you suspect me of so uncommon vulgar a sensation. I trust my joy is occasion'd by ideas more becoming a woman of fashion—I am charm'd because his fortune is large▪ his family ancient; and because my marriage will render all my female friends so uncommon miserable; and because I suspect that Ellen met young Stanley at Spa, and that she dares aspire to—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: I wish she were out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: No—she shall stay to witness my triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Shall stay—I'm not to be contradicted, you know—my physicians—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Certainly not, my dear Nabob; but I may re∣commend; I'm sure no physician would object to your taking advice. Ah! does Ellen love you as I do?—will she listen to your speech as I intend to do?—would she throw away thousands for you in a night as I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Very true! very true! Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.—A Pleasure Ground, and View of an ancient Castle.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter four Servants dress'd in old-fashion'd liveries, then Sir HUBERT STANLEY and HEARTLEY.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Good Heartly, is all prepar'd for my boy's re∣ception, his favourite study on the southern battlement?— Are his dogs train'd—his hunters well condition'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: To say truth, Sir Hubert, the castle has been all day in quarrel, each servant claiming the right of exclusive attendance on his dear young master.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: I thank their honest loves. He writes me he is well, good Heartly; quite well.—Ha! the village bells proclaim my boys arrival.—Dost thou hear the people's shouts?

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Aye, and it revives my old heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: These welcomes are the genuine effusions of love and gratitude—Spite of this Nobobs arts, you see how my loving neighbours respect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Where is my boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Not yet arriv'd, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: These rejoicings are for the Nabob's daughter, who is just come from London.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Indeed! (peeishly) Well, well.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My young master will alight privately at Oatland's farm, and walk through the park. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: The Nabob's daughter!—Well, let it pass.— Heartly, what said farmer Oatland?

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Nothing but what profligacy and insolence dictated —he defied your power, and sent to the Nabob

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Ungrateful man! let a distress be issued.—Hold; no, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Indeed Sir Hubert, he is undeserving your lenity.— Besides, sir, your mortgage; Mr. Rapid, the wealthy tay∣lor, will be here to day—the interest on the mortgage must be paid—some of your election bills remain unliquidated, and I fear, without a further mortgage—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Don't torture. Pardon me, good old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Truly, Sir Hubert, what might have been effected with 5000l. some years ago, will now require ten—you must retrench your hospitable benevolence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: My worthy steward, my head has long acknow∣ledg'd the truth of your arithmetic—but my head could never teach it to my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: And, sir, you may raise your rents.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Never, Heartley—never.—what! shall the many suffer that I may be at ease!—But away with care—this is a moment devoted to exstasy—this is the hour a doating father is to clasp an only child, who, after combating with disease and death, returns triumphant to his arms in lusty health and manhood.—Ah! he approaches; 'tis my boy—Dost thou not see him in the beechen avenue.—Dull old man, advance thine hand thus— (putting his hand over his forehead). —See how his eyes wander with delight, and renovate the pictures of his youth.—Ah! now he sees his father, and flies like lightning.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles
SP.P: My honour'd—my lov'd father!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Rise to my heart.—Stand off, and let my eyes gloat upon thee—thou art well.—Thy arm good Heartley— Nay, do not weep, old honesty, twill infect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ah▪ my excellent old friend—in health I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Aye, good master, and this day will make me young again.

Dear father, already must I become a suitor to
you.—Passing Oatland's farm, I found his lovely daughter Jessy in tears, occasion'd by her father's inability to pay his rent. I dried them with a promise— (HEARTLEY shakes his head, and Sir HUBERT averts his face). —Ha! your brow is clouded with unhappiness;—pray sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Good Heartley, leave us— (Exeunt HEARTLEY and Servants). —Charles, so mix'd is the cup of life, that this day, the happiest thy old father can e'er hope to see, is dash'd with bitterness and sorrow, boy. I've been a very unthrift to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Oh, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Listen to me.—You have heard how my father kept alive the benevolent hospitality that once distinguish'd old England, and I not finding in modern ethics aught likely to improve either the morals or happiness of mankind, deter∣min'd to persevere in the ways of my fathers. Soon after you went abroad, the adjoining estate was purchas'd by an East Indian, groaning under wealth produc'd by groans. Like the viper, after collecting in the warm sunshine his bag of venom, he came to the abode of peace and innocence, and disseminated his poison. But mark me—think me not so un∣just, boy, as with random slander to censure any body of men. No, thank heaven; there are numbers whom Providence, in addition to the power, has added the will, to render wealth a blessing to all around them.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: You are ever just and liberal.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: But for this vile exception, this Mr. Vortex, I tell thee, riot, contention▪ indolence, and vice succeeded. I struggled against this mischief, which spurr'd him on to op∣pose me in my election. This contest [I trust, Charles, you think the dignity of our family demanded it]—this contest, I say, oblig'd me to mortgage my estate to a considerable amount; and I fear, boy, even that will not suffice. Dost thou not blame th father?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Blame, sir? my fortune nay, my life, is hed but to promote your happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Glorious boy! then all will be well again; thy estate restor'd, thy wealth enlarg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: By marriage, Charles.— [Charles averts his face with dejection.]

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P:
Marriage, sir! To conceal the passion that tri∣umphs here were but to deceive a father, and injure the bright
excellence I love. When I was ill at Spa, the votaries of pleasure avoided me as the harbinger of melancholy, and I was despis'd as a thing passing into obivion by all but one fair creature. I obtaind an opportunity to thank her for the charitable pity her eye had beam'd on me. Love soon kin∣dled his torch at Pitys altar, for I found in Miss Vortex such excelence—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Who?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Miss Vortex, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: From India?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: The same.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Hub.
SP.P: She that is now propos'd for your alliance.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: And awaits your arrival in the neighbourhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Oh! let me haste to her.—Yet hold! Frank Oatland attends to hear your determination.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: At present, Charles, I cannot grant your suit. — (CHARLES beckons in FRANK.) —Young man, tell your Father the law must take its course. When I see in him symptoms of contrition and amendment, I may restore him.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Thank ye,—thank ye, sur.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: How came this distress to fall on him?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, sur, he went on farmering pretty tightish, did'nt he, sur? till he keep't company wi' Nabob's sarvants; then, all of a sudden, he took to the gentleman line. I conceats, sur, he did'nt much understand the trim on't, for the gentleman line didn't answer at all. I hope your honour bean't angry wi' I for speaking to young 'Squire; your worship to know I were a bit of a playfellow w' un, and we followed our studies together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: Ees, sur, we went through our letters—and a-b ab—e-b eb—there somehow I stuck, and 'Squire went clean away into abrevivation and abomination; and then I never cou'd take much to your pens, they be so cruel small; now a pitch-fork do fit my hand so desperate kindly as never was.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Ha! ha! Come, my boy, youll want refresh∣ment. Exit. FRANK bows, and is going.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: What, honest Frank, will you not walk with me to the castle;

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: If your honour be so gracious.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Nay, wear your hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: O dear! O dear! what a pity nobody do see I.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Come, brother student, your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My hand! Lord dong it, only think o' I:

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.— A Room in an Inn.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter two Waiters with luggage, meeting BRONZE.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Waiter.
SP.P: Coming, sir▪

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (without). Zounds, why don't you come? Why dont all of you come, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Waiter, who are these people?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Waiter.
SP.P: I dont know. Mr. Bronze.—The young one seems a queer one; he jumpd out of the mail ran into the kitchen, whippd the turnspit into a gallop, and bade him keep moving; and tho not a minute in the house, he had been in every room, from the garret to the cellar.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Waiter.
SP.P: Father and son, I understand.—The name on the luggage I see, is Rapid.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Rapid! (aside). Perhaps it is my old master the great taylor and his harum-scarum son—I'll observe.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Waiter.
SP.P: Here he comes full dash, and the old man trotting after him like a terrier. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Come along, dad—push on, my dear dad. Well, here we are—keep moving.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: Moving! Zounds havn't I been moving all night in the mail-coach, to please you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Mail! famous thing, isn't it? Jeup! whip over counties in a hop, step and jump—dash along

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Od rot such hurry-scurry doings, I say. Here have I ground my old bones all night in the mail, to be eight hours before my appointment with Sir Hubert Stanley—and now I must sit biting my fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Biting your fingers! No, no, Il find you some∣thing to do. Come, well keep moving! (Takes his father by the arm who resists.)

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Gentlemen, I beg leave—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: No prosing—to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: For shame—dont interrupt the gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Gently dad. Dash away sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Land
SP.P: servant of Sir Hubert Stanley has been inquir∣ing for Mr. Rid.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Push on!

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: And expects him at the castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That will do—push off—brush—run! Exit Landlord (running.) That's the thing—keep moving. I say, dad!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What do you say, Neddy?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Neddy! dam it, don't call me Neddy. I hate to be call'd Neddy.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Well, I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That's settled. I say, What's your business with Sir Hubert?—Some secret, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: (aside) I won't tell you. Oh no—a bill he owes me for making his cloaths and liveries.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Pugh! he's a ready-money man. I never made a bill out for him in my life.—It won't do.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: Well, then, sit down, and Ill tell you (they sit.) Can you sit still a moment?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (jumping up.) To be sure I can—Now tell me briefly—briefly. Sits again.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: (aside) Indeed I will not, you must know—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Aye—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: You must know—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Zounds! you have said that twice—now don't say it again.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Well, I won't—You must know—'tis a very long story.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (rising.) Then I'll not trouble you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: (aside.) I thought so. And pray what might induce you to come with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (aside.) Won't tell him of Jessy. Oh, as we had given up trade, left off stitching—you know my way—I like to push on—change the scene, that's all—keep moving.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: Moving! (yawns). Oh, my poor old bones! Water, bring me a night-gown. (Waiter helps him on with a night-gown—he lays his coat on a chair.)

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What are you at, dad?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Going to take a nap on that sofa.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: A nap—pugh!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: Zounds! I've no comfort of my life with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Say no more.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: But I will tho'—hurry, hurry—od rabbit it, I never get a dinner that's half dressed; and as for a comfort∣able sleep, I'm sure—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: You sleep so slow.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Sleep slow! Ill sleep as slow as I please; so at your peril disturb me. Sleep slow indeed! (yawning).

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Now to visit Jessy. Waiter!

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Sar (with great quickness).

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That's right—sir—short—you're a fine fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Yes, sar.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Does Farmer Oatland live hereabouts?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Yes, sar.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: How far?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Three miles.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Which way?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: West.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That will do—get me a buggy.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Yes, sar.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, if my old dad had left off business as some of your flashy taylors do, I might have kept a curracle, and liv'd like a man. Is the buggy ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: No, sar.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: But to cut the shop with paltry five thousand. —Is the buggy ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: No, sar.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Or to have dash'd to Jessy in a curracle.—Is the buggy ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: No, sar. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: To have flank'd along a pair of blood things at sixteen miles an hour (Puts himself in the act of driving, and sits on the chair where OLD RAPID left his coat—springs from it again.) What the devil's that? Zounds, something has run into my back Ill bet a hundred tis a needle in Father's pocket Confound it! what does he carry needles now for? (Searches the pocket) Sure enough, here it is—one end stuck into a letter, and the other into my back I believe. Curse it! Eh! whats this? Reads "To Mr. Rapid— Free—Hubert Stanley. Ha ha, ha! here's dads secret —Now for it! (Reads very quick). Sir Hubert Stanley will expect to see Mr Rapid at the Castle and would be gad to extend the mortgage, which is now 50,000 l. What's this? (Reads again) —Extend the mortgage, which is now 50,000 l to seventy. Fift thousand! huzza! 'tis so—my old dad worth fifty thousand—perhaps seventy—perhaps—I'll—no—I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: The buggy's ready, sar.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Dare to talk to me of a buggy, and I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Perhaps you wou'd prefer a chaise and pair?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: No, I'll have a chaise and twelve Abscond! (Exit Waiter.) I must—I must keep moving.—I must tra∣vel for improvement First Ill see the whole of my native country, its agriculture and manufactories That, I think, will take me full four days and a half Next Ill make the tour of Europe; which, to do properly, will, I dare say, employ three weeks or a month. Then returning as complete∣ly vers'd in foreign manners and languages as the best of them, I'll make a push at high life. In the first circles Ill keep moving. Fifty thousand! perpaps more—perhaps—oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter
SP.P: (without) You can't come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze
SP.P: (without). I tell you I will come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap,
SP.P: Will come in!—thats right—push on, whoever you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: I thought so. How do you do Mr. Rapid? Dont you remember Bronze, your father's foreman, when you were a boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Ah, Bronze! how do you do, Bronze? Any thing to say, Bronze? Keep moving. Do you know, Bronze, by this letter I have discover'd, that my father is worth—how much think you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Perhaps ten thousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Push on.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze,
SP.P: Twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Push on.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Thirty.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap
SP.P: Keep moving.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze
SP.P: Forty.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Fifty—perhaps—sixty—seventy—oh! I'll tell you. He has lent 50 000 l. on mortgage, to an old Baronet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Sir Hubert St—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (stopping him). I know his name as well as you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze
SP.P: (aside). Heres news for my master! Well sir, what do you mean to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Do! Push on—become a man of fashion, to be sure

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze
SP.P: What wou'd you say, if I were to get you intro∣duced to a Nabob?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: A Nabob! Oh! some flash-in-the-pan chap.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Oh▪ no!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What, one of your real, genuine, neat-as-im∣ported Nabob's?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Yes; Mr. Vortex.—Did you never hear of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: To be sure I have. But will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Ah! but will you do it directly?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Then push off—Stop—stop—I beg your pardon —it cuts me to the heart to stop any man▪ because I wish every body to keep moving. But won't dad's being a taylor make an objection?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: No; as you never went out with the pattern-books.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap,
SP.P: (sighing). Oh! yes, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: That's aukward—But you never operated?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rapid.
SP.P: [with melancholy]. What do you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: I say you never.— [describes in action the act of sewing.]

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (sighing deeper). Oh! yes I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: That's unlucky.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Very melancholy, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: I have it. Suppose I say you are merchants.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: My dear fellow, sink the taylor, and I'll give you a hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Will you? thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Now push off.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: But don't be out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Me! Bless you, I'm always in the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Don't move.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Yes, I must move a little—away you go— (pushes Bronze off). Huzza! now to awake old dad▪ (Exit, and returns with OLD RAPID.) Come along dad.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: half asleep. Yes, sir,—yes, sir—I'll measure you directly—I'll measure you directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: He's asleep.—Awake!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What's the matter, eh? What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What's the matter! I've found fifty thousand in that letter?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Indeed! (opens the letter eagerly). Ah! Neddy, have you found out—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I have—that you are worth—how much?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Why, since what's past—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Never mind what's past.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Ive been a fortunate man. My old partner us'd to say, Ah! you are lucky, Rapid. Your needle always sticks in the right place.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: No, not always (shrugging). But how much?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Why, as it must out, there are fifty thousand lent on mortgage. Item fifteen thousand in the Consols—Item—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Never mind the Items.—The total my dear dad —the total.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What do you think of a plum?

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: A plum! Oh, sweet, agreeable, little short word!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Besides seven hundred and ninety—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Never mind the odd money—that will do. But how came you so rich, dad? Dam'me, you must have kept moving.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Why, my father, forty years ago, left me five thousands pounds; which, at compound interest, if you multiply—

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: No; you have multiplied it famously. It's my business to reduce it (aside). Now, my dear dad, in the first place▪ never call me Neddy.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Why, what must I call you

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Ned—short—Ned.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Ned! O Ned!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap▪
SP.P: That will do. And in the next place, sink the taylor Whatever you do, sink the taylor.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Sink the taylor! What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Ive news for you. We are going to be intro∣duced to Mr. Vortex▪ the rich Nabob.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: You don't say so! Huzza; it will be the mak∣ing of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: To be sure. Such fashion! such stile!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Aye, and such a quantity of liveries, and—Oh dear me! (with great dejection.)

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: (sighing.) I forgot I had left off business.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Business! Confound it! Now, pray keep the taylor under, will you? Ill—Ill send an express to Lon∣don (runs to the table.)

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: An express for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I don't know.—

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: The bill of fare, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Bring it here [reads.] Turbots—Salmon— Soles—Haddock—Beef—Mutton—Veal—Lamb—Pork Chickens—Ducks—Turkies—Puddings—Pyes. —Dress it all—thats the short way.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter
SP.P: All!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Every bit.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: No, no, nonsense.—The short way indeed! Come here, sir.—Let me see— (reads.) "Um—Um.— Ribs of beef" —Thats a good thing;—I'll have that.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Ribs of beef, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Are they the short ribs?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: That's right.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: What liquor wou'd your honour like?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: [jumping up.] Spruce beer.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Very well, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I must have some clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: I'm sure that's a very good coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Waiter!—I must have a dashing coat for the Nabob. Is there a rascally taylor any where near you?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Yes, sir;—there are two close by (Father and Son look at each other.)

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Umph! Then tell one of them to send me some clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Sir, he must take your measure.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: To be sure he must.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, true! I remember the fellows do measure you somehow with long bits of—Well—send for the scoun∣drel. Exit Waiter.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, for shame of yourself? I've no patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Like you the better—Hate patience as much as you do,—ha! ha!—Must swagger a little.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: Ah! I am too fond of you, I am, Ned. Take my fortune; but only remember this—By the faith of a man I came by it honestly—and all I ask is, that it may go as it came.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Certainly. But we must keep moving you know.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Well, I don't care if I do take a bit of a walk with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Bit of a walk! Dam'me, we'll have a gallop together. Come along, dad.—Push on dad. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—A Room in Mr. VORTEX'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. VORTEX, ELLEN, and Miss VORTEX.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen
SP.P: Married to Charles Stanley! You, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Yes, I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: I'll not believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Well, I vow that's uncommon comic. And why not, my forsaken cousin?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: First, madam, I know Charles Stanley would only form so sacred an alliance where his affections pointed out the object. Secondly, I feel those affections to be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Thirdly, an inconstant swain was a thing never heard of; and to conclude, pray peruse that letter—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen
SP.P: [reads▪] Sir Hubert Stanley informs Mr. Vortex that his son embraces with eager joy the proposals for his marriage with Mr. Vortex's daughter. (Drops the letter.) Then every thing is possible. Oh, love!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Nay, don't you abuse poor Cupid—his conduct has been perfectly parliamentary. Self-interest has made the little gentleman move over to the other side, that's all. (Knock∣ing at the door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Heavens! should this be—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Young Mr. Stanley, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: My soul sinks within me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: (with affected tenderness). Upon my honour, my dear, you had better retire.—Your agitation—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: I thank you, madam (going). Hold.—No;— with your permission I'll remain (returns).

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Just as you please. What a triumph! Oh, how uncommon delicious!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Now, heart, be firm! [Retires from the front of the stage].

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: How hes struck!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: What can this mean? [aside.] Ma—mad—madam —the confusion that —that—that—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: I must cheer him with a smile. (During this ELLEN advances to the front of the stage so as to leave Miss VRTEX between her and STANLEY.)

SP.SPEAKER: Charles
SP.P:
[seeing ELLEN]. Ah! what heaven of brightness
breaks in upon me! Lovely Miss Vortex, can I believe my happiness? Will those arms receive me? (Miss VORTEX, thinking this addressed to her, opens her arms; STANLEY rushes past her to ELLEN) My Ellen!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Oh▪ Charles▪ the sufferings my heart underwent this moment and the joy it now feels is such, I cannot speak. (They retire.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Nabob! Nabob!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: The matter! won't you resent this?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh dear! not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Will you bear an insult?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: My physicians order me not to mind being insult∣ed at all; nothing is to provoke me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Provoke you!—If I were a man I would—Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I don't like his looks—he seems a desperate—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: What do you mean to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Vor.
SP.P: Why▪ as this is a very extraordinary case—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Certainly

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I think it best to—adjourn (goes up the stage, Miss VORTEX follows).

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I perceive the mistake; but my heart confess'd but one Miss Vortex.—I thought the name, like the supe∣rior virtues you adorn it with attach'd alone to Ellen. The embarrassments of my paternal estate demanded a marriage with a woman of fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: What do I hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Why this alarm?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen
SP.P: Alarm! Must not those words terrify which sepa∣rate me from you for ever?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: What means my Ellen?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Oh, Stanley, hear me On my return to England, Mr. Vortex, to whom the care of my property was entrusted, was ever pressing on my mind the difficulty of recovering my father's India possessions. Each messenger that arrived from you, confirmed the melancholy tale▪ that my Stanley was sinking into an early grave. Oh! what then was fortune or the world to me? I sought out solitude, and willingly to Mr Vortex what he called my expectations, thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Yet you shall be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: No, Charles, I will not bring you poverty. I'll return to solitude and endeavour to teach this lesson to my heart, that it will be joy enough to know that Stanley is wel and happy, (Going)

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Stay, Ellen—think deeply before you consign the man that loves you to certain misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: True—in a few hours let me see you again. The opposing agitations my mind has suffered unfit me for further conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: In a few hours, then, you'll allow me to see you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Allow you to see me!—Oh! Stanley, fare∣well! Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Mr. and Miss VORTEX come forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Now speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: We had better pair off.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: No—speak with spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I will—Sir, I cannot help saying, that every man▪ that is, every man of honor—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Thats right!—say that again.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: That every man of honor (raising his voice).

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Well, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Is—is—the—the—best judge of his own actions.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I perfectly agree with you—and wish you a good morning. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: So, then, I'm to be insulted, despis'd and laughd at, and no duel is to take place—no body is to be kill'd—my tender heart is to feel no satisfaction— (weeps.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I fight!—Do you consider the preciousness of a legislator's life?
"A country suffers when a Member bleeds."

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Oh, sir, such news!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: What! is parliament convened?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: No, sir; but I have found out that the Baronet is—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: What of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Ruin'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: (drying her eyes.) Well! that's some satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P:
I met at the inn the Mr. Rapids, merchants I liv'd with, who have a large mortgage on his estate, and he wants to borrow more—So, sir, I told them I was
sure my master would be proud to see them at Bangalore Hl, because I thought, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I know—I have it. I'll shew them every atten∣tion; and if I can but get hold of the mortgage, I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: Oh! uncommon charming!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: (to Miss VORTEX). Now do you go and write a note, and say we will wait on them.—Ah! use policy instead of pistols, and I would fight any man—for, as I say in my speech, "Policy, Mr. Speaker, is—"

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Exactly, Nabob—but I must write the letter, you know. Is the young merchant handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Yes, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: So much the better. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: You see, Bronze, the turn I give it is this— "Policy, Mr. Speaker▪ says I—"

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Very true, sir; but I believe my mistress calls—I attend you, madam. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Confound it! Will nobody hear my speech? then I'll speak it to myself.—"Policy Mr. Speaker—"

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: How do you do, sur.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: What! interrupted again?—Approach, don't be afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Lord, sur, I bean't afeard: Why should I?—I defies the devil and all his works.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: If this be what is called rough honesty, give me a little smooth-tongu'd roguery. I don't know you, fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees, sur, you do—I be's Frank Oatland.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Begone! I know nothing of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees, sur, you do—I've a bit of a sister call'd Jessy.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Eh! ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: (aside). Dom um, he knaws me well enough now.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh! very true—Frank Oatland, aye! Well, good Frank▪ how is Jessy?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Charming sur! charming!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Aye, that she is, lovely and charming, indeed! (aside). —And how are you, Frank?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I be's charming too, sur!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: But why don't Jessy visit my people here? I should be always happy to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Should you, sur? Why, if I may be so bold as ax, why, sur?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Because—because—she is—a—farmer Oatland's child.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: So be I, sur How comes it, then, that you never axes I to your balls and ostentations? I can dance twice as long as sister can.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Cunning fellow this!—I must buy him. Well, Frank, what are your commands?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, sur, Feyther do command you to lend him three hundred pounds—no, sur, I mean he supplicates.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex▪
SP.P: Three hundred pounds!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: I'll tell you, sur, all about it.—You knaw, sur, Feyther have been knuckled out of a most cruel sight of money by you at weagering and cards.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: By me fellow! Do you think I associate with such reptiles?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ecod it was either you or t'other gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: T'other gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I dan't knaw which be which, not I.—There be two of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Two of us!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees; there be you—that be one;—and there be your gentleman—he do make the pair.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: The pair!—and have I been buying a hundred thousand pounds worth of respect for this? Have I become a Member to pair off with my valet?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ecod, and a comical pair you be!—T'other gen∣tleman be's a tightish, conceated sort of a chap enough;— but you be a little—he! he! (smothering a laugh).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Upon my soul, this is very pleasant—You are quite free and easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Quite, sur; quite. Feyther do tell I it be all the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: He does! Then you may tell Feyther, that if he has lost his money at play, the winners won't give him six∣pence to save him from starving, and that be all the fashion. —By their distress the pretty Jessy will be more in my power, and then I can reinstate them in a farm upon terms (aside.) Go, fellow! I shall not send your Father sixpence.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: The words I told um—the very words I told um. —Says I— "Feyther he bean't the man will gi' thee a brass fathing. Dong it, he hasn't it here, says I" (laying his upon his heart).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: You said so▪ did you?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees—so you see, sur, what a desperate cute lad I be.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: (aside). Ill set a trap for you, you dog—I'll have you in my power, however; Ill drop my purse—he'll take it—and then— (drops his purse) —A pair of us! I'll lay you by the heels, desperate cute as you are. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: Poor Feyther, poor sister, and poor I! Feyther will go broken hearted, for artain;—and then, sister Jessy's coming to labour.—I can't bear the thought on Od dom thee if I could but get hold of some of thy money Id teak care thee should not get it again — Eh! (ses the purse, walks round it) Well, now, I declare that do look for al the world like a purse How happy it would make poor Feyther and sister▪ I conceates there woud be no harm just to touch it;— (takes it up with caution;) it be cruel tempting. No∣body do see I —I wonder how it woud feel in my pocket (puts it with fear into his pocket). Wouns! how hot I be! Cruel warm to be sure. Who's that? Nobody.—Oh! l— l—l-u-d, lud! and I ha' gotten such a desperate ague all of a sudden,—and my heart do keep j—jump—jumping—I be∣lieve I be going to die (falls into a chair) Eh!—Eh!—May∣hap it be this terrible purse. Dom thee, come out (throws it down — After a pause) Ees, now I is better.—Dear me, quite an alteration.—My head doant spin about soa, and my heart do feel as light, and do so keep tittuping, tittuping, I can't help crying.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Now I have him.— (Sees the purse). What, he has not stole it, tho' his own Father's in want!—Here's a precious rascal for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
Vortex.
SP.P: My purse! True; reach in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Noa, thank you for nothing —I've had it my hand once.—Ecod, if having other peoples money do make a man so hot, how desperate warm some folks mun be!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Warm.—foolish fellow▪ (wiping his forehead, and fanning himself with his hat) Fugh! quite a Bengal day, I declare.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Od dang it! how their wicked heads round!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Spin round! I never heard such a simpleton.— Spin, indeed! ha! ha! God bless my soul, I'm quite giddy! Oh Lord! Oh dear me! Help! help!

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: What's the matter, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Only a little touch of my old complaint.—Send that fellow away. [BRONZE goes up to FRANK.]

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Oh, this be t'other genteman. Sur, I ha' gotten twenty-six pound that Feyther lost to you at gamestering.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze.
SP.P: Where is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: In my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Bronze
SP.P: That's lucky! give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Gi' it thee! Ees, dom thee, come out, and I'll gi' it thee (clenching his fist.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Begone!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Gentlemen, I wish you both a good morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: (getting up.) What a dunderhead that is! To suppose that a little tenderness of conscience wou'd make a man's head turn round.—Pugh! 'tis impossible;—or how the devil woud the Lawyers find their way from Westminster∣hall? Giddy, indeed! Ha! ha!—Bronze, take care I don't fall. Exit, leaning on BRONZE.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—A Room in an Inn.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter OLD RAPID with a Letter, and a Servant following.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: What! a real letter from the real Nabob—Dear me! where is Neddy?—Make my humble duty to your master; proud to serve him—no—very proud to see him;— grateful for the honour of his custom—no—no—for his company.—I wish you a pleasant walk home sir—The Nabob coming here directly. Oh dear me! where's Neddy? —Waiter! Exit Servant.
Do you know where my boy is?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter
SP.P: Not a minute ago I saw him fighting in a field behind the house

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Fighting!—Oh, dear where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Here am I, dad.—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What has been the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Y▪ Rap▪
SP.P: Only a small rumpus;—went to peep at the castle, —pushing home,—the road had a bit of a circumbendibus— hate corners,—so I jumped the hedge—cut right across,— you know my way,—kept moving,—up came a farmer,— wanted to turn me back,—would not do,—tussled a bit —carried my point,—came straight as an arrow.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Fie, fie!—But read that letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What! the Nabob coming her directly, and I in this pickle.—Waiter, are my cothes come home?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter
SP.P: No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Why, the felow gave his word—

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Yes, sir;—but what can you expect from a tay∣lor? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That's very true.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Impudent rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: What the devil shall I do? The most important moment of my life.—

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: 'Tis unlucky.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Unlucky?—'Tis perdition—annihilation—a misfortune, that—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: I can mend.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: By mending the coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: An excellent thought.—Come help me off▪— quick,—quick!

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap
SP.P: always have a needle in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: (rubbing his back.) I know you have.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: Now give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: What! suffer my Father to mend my coat?— No,—no;—not so bad as that neither.—As the coat must be mended,—damn it, Ill mend it.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap
SP.P: Will you tho?—Ecod, I should like to see you; —here's a needle ready threaded—and a thimble;—you can't think how I shal like to see you;—dont hurry, thats a dear boy [YOUNG RAPID sits down, gathers his legs under him—OLD RAPID puts his spectacles on and sits close to him, looking on]

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Now mind, dad, when—Damn the needle!

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: Thats because you are in such a hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap
SP.P: When the Nabob comes,—sink the taylor.—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: I will;—but thats a long stitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Be sure you sink the taylor;—a great deal de∣pends on the first impression;—you shall be reading a grave book with a melancholy air.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Then I wish I had brought down my book of bad debts;—that would have made me melancholy enough.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. and Miss VORTEX, who advance slowly, the Nabob the side where YOUNG RAPID is, Miss VORTEX to the other side.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I.—ha! ha! I say, dad, if the Nabob was to see us now,—ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Ha! ha! True;—but mind what you're about.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I'll be discovered in a situation that will surprize —a striking situation, and in some damn'd elegant attitude [looks up and sees the Nabob.]

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Why dont you finish the job!—why don't you? (sees the Nabob)—(They look round the other way and see Miss VORTEX; they both appear ashamed and dejected; YOUNG RAPID draws his legs from under him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Gentlemen,—I and my daughter, Miss Vortex, have done ourselves the honour of waiting upon you, to—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: But I beg we may not interrupt your amuse∣ment;—'tis uncommon whimsical!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: (recovering himself.) Yes ma'am, very whimsi∣cal,—I must keep moving [laughs] Ha! ha! You see, dad. 've won,—Ive won—ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: He says he has won—

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: (with amazement.) Oh! he has won, has he?

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: Yes, you know I've won; he! he! why don't you laugh? (aside to OLD RAPID).

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: with difficulty. Ha he!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: You see, maam the fact is,—I had torn my coat; so says I to my father, Ill bet my bays against your opera box that I mend it; and so—ha! ha! (to OLD RAPID) laugh again.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: I can't—indeed I can't.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: And so I—I won—upon my soul I was doing it very well.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: No, you were not,—you were doing it a shame to be seen

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (apart) Hush!—Ah▪ father you don't like to lose.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Wel, gentlemen, now this very extraordinary frolic is over—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Yes, sir,—it is quite over,— (aside) thank Heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Suppose we adjourn to Bangalore Hall?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Sir. I'll go with you directly with all the plea∣sure in life [running]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: I believe my curricle is the first carriage.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Dear me! [looking at Miss VORTEX.]

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: My daughter seems to please you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What a shape!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Oh, sir, you're uncommon polite.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: He's remarkably gallant, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What elegance!—what fashion!—upon the whole, it's the best made little spencer I've seen for some time. (VORTEX and Daughter in amazement.)

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, the devil!—The fact is, ma'am, my father is the most particular man on earth about dress—the beau of his time—Beau Rapid.—You know, father, they always call'd you Beau Rapid.—I dare say he's had more suits of clothes in his house than any man in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: An uncommon expensive whim!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I don't think his fortune has suffer'd by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: (to OLD RAPID). Shall I have the honour of driving you?

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: Oh, madam, I can't think of giving you so much trouble as to drive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: My dear sir▪—I shall be uncommon happy!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, madam! (simpers and titters to his son, then takes Miss VORTEX's hand and trots off).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: We'll follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: If you please;—not that I particularly like to follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I suppose sir, now summer approaches, London begins to fill for the winter.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Any thing new in high life?—what is the pre∣sent rage with ladies of fashion?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Why, sir, as to the ladies;— (aside) What shall I say?—Oh, the ladies, sir—why, heaven bless them, ! they—they keep moving;—but, to confess the truth, sir; my fashionable education has been very much neglected.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: That's a pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Very great pity, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Suppose I become your preceptor.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: If you wou'd be so kind—I wou'd treasure any little short rule.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Why there is a short rule necessary for every man of fashion to attend to.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Never to reflect.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Never reflect!—what, push on—keep moving! —My dear sir—that's my way—suits me exactly.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Then you must be known.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: To be sure;—I'll give away thousands in cha∣rities.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Charities!—You wou'd be forgot in a week.— To be known, you must be mischievous;—malice has a much better memory than gratitude;—and then you must be gal∣lant.—Are there no pretty girls you should like to be well with, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: A very extensive assortment, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: And perhaps there may be a married woman you would like to intrigue with.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: A very large quantity.—Oh, how I long to begin!—Are you married, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Why, no!

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: The carriage is ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: So am I; come, sir,—four horses, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That's a great pity. Pray, sir, will you have the goodness to tell your coachman to drive like the devil?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Sir▪ to oblige you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Sir, I ll be very much obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Your clothes are come, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That's lucky.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Then I ll wait for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Wait for me! nobody need wait for me—I ll be with you in a crack—Do you push on—I ll keep mov∣ing—I ll take care nobody waits for me. Exeunt severally.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—A Room in the Nabob's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter OATLAND dejected, FRANK and JESSY leading him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Be comforted, Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: To see thee brought to service! (sighs). —I've done this; I that should have—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: Never mind—we be young and healthy, and don't heed it—do us, Jessy?

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: To be ashamd to look my own chidren in the face —I, who ought to have been the fore-horse of the team, to be pull'd along through life by this young tender thing!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Dont despond, Father — Sir Hubert will see your contrition, and restore you to his favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: When the hen sees the hawk ready to pounce, she gather's her young ones under her wing—when misfortune hovers over my sweet chicken here, I leave her to shift for herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Come, no more of this

SP.SPEAKER: Oat
SP.P: Even the savage hawk takes care of its nestlings— what then am I?—Children, do you hate me?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hate thee! pugh, Feyther, dan't thee talk so— good bye to thee— cheer up— Thee has long been a Feyther to me, now its my turn, and I'll be a Feyther to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Oat.
SP.P: I cannot speak—take care of my girl, Frank. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Care of her!—though she be a sarvant, let me catch any body striking her, that's all.—Well▪ Jessy, we mun not be sheam'd—I know poverty be no sin, because par∣son said so last Sunday. Talk of that—I do hear that your sweetheart, Mr. Rapid, be worth such a desperate sight of money as never was!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: (sighs). If his fortunes are so prosperous, brother, he is exated above my hopes—if his heart be mercenary, he is sunk below my wishes.—Heigh-ho! yet he might have sent to know if I were well, he might—no matter!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: He be coming to Neabob's here, on a visitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Ah! coming here!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees—and Mr. Bronze do say while he be here I am to be his sarving man.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: You his servant! (weeps).

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Don't thee cry, Jessy!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: (recovering herself). I won't; it was weak, it was wrong.—Frank▪ be sure you conceal from Mr. Rapid who you are—I have reasons for it.—Edward here!—when we meet it will be a hard trial. Yet why should I dread it?— let perfidy and pride shrink abash'd, virtuous integrity will support me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: That's right. Jessy, shew a proper spirit—Ecod, if he were to pull out his purse and to offer to make thee a present of five guineas, don't thee take it.— (JESY smiles dejectedly.) —Here be the new mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Dost thou hear? Dom it, dant't thee take it!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Oh! my new attendent, I suppose!—What's your name, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: Jessy Oatland, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Wel, Oatland, (taking out glass,) look at me.—Umph—not at all contemptible.—That's a charming nosegay— JESSY presents it) —all exotics, I declare.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: No, Madam, neglected with wild flowers—I took them from the bed of weeds, bestowed care on their culture, and, by transplanting them to a more genial soil, they have flourished with luxuriant strength and beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: A pretty amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: And it seemd, madam▪ to convoy this lession— Nor to despise the lowly mind, but rather, with fostering hand to draw it from its chill obscurity, that, like those humble flowers▪ it might grow rich in native energy

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Oh! (aside) —mind energy!—What's the▪ matter with the poor girl I wonder! uncommon odd!—I hear, Oat and you are reduced in your circumstances.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Yes, madam.
Thats very lucky, because it will make you humbe, child!—Well, and what are your qualifications?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Cheerful industry, madam. I can read to you, write for you, or converse—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Converse with me! I dare say you can.— No, thank you, child instead of my listening to your voice, you will be polite enough to be as silent as convenient▪ and do me the honour of listening to mine—Oh! here comes Mr Rapid.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.

SP.P: Yes; I shall follow to dress. No, stay. Yes, you may go.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: Oh, thank you! thank you, dear madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: That poor girl appears to me rather crazy.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter OLD and YOUNG RAPID, and VORTEX.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Welcome to Bangalore Hall, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: Charming house! plenty of room!— (Runs about and looks at every thing)

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: A very spacious apartment, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Yes, sir; but I declare I forgot the dimensions of this room.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Sir, if you please, I ll measure it—my cane is exactly a yard, good honest measure—'tis handy—and that mark is the half yard, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (Overhears, and snatches the cane from him.) Con∣found it!—The pictures, father—look at the pictures (point∣ing with the cane;) did you ever see such charming—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Do you like pictures?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Exceedingly, ma'am; but I should like them a great deal better if they just moved a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Ha! ha! I must retire to dress—till dinner, gentlemen, adieu. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (to his Father.) Zounds! you'll ruin every thing! —Can't you keep the taylor under.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Your son seems rather impatient.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Very, sir—always was.—I remember a certain Duke—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: That's right, lay the scene high; push the Duke; push him as far as he'll go.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: I will, I will.—I remember a certain Duke used to say, Mr. Rapid, your son is as sharp as a needle.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: At it again!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: As a needle—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (interrupting him.) Is true to the pole. As a needle is true to the pole, says the Duke; so will your son, says the Duke, be to every thing spirited and fashionable, says the Duke.—Am I always to be tortured with your infernal needles? (aside to OLD RAPID.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Now to sound them.—I hear, gentlemen, your business in this part of the country is with Sir Hubert Stanley, respecting some money transactions.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: 'Tis a secret, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh! no—the Baronet avows his wish to sell his estate.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Oh! that alters the case.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I think that it would be a desirable purchase for you—I should be happy in such neighbours—and if you should want forty or fifty thousand, ready money, I'll sup∣ply it with pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, how kind!—If my son wishes to purchase, I would rather leave it entirely to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: And I would rather leave it entirely to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Very well, I'll propose for it·— (aside) This will cut Sir Hubert to the soul.—There is a very desirable borough interest—then you could sit in Parliament.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I in Parliament? ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: No; that would be a botch.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: No▪ no, I was once in the gallery—crammed in—no moving—expected to hear the great guns—up got a litte fellow, nobody knew who, gave us a three hours speech —I got dev'lish fidgetty—the House called for the question, I join'd the cry—"The question, the question!" says I — A Member spied me—clear'd the gallery—got hustl'd by my brother spectators—obliged to scud—Oh! it would never do for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: But you must learn patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Then make me Speaker—if that wou'dn't teach me patience, nothing would.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Do you dislike, sir, Parliamentary eloquence?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Sir, I never heard one of your real downright Parliament speeches in my life—never (yawns).

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: By your yawning I shou'd think you had heard a great many.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh, how lucky!—At last I shall get my dear speech spoken.—Sir▪ I am a Member, and I mean to—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Keep moving.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Why, I mean to speak, I assure you; and—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Push on, then.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: What, speak my speech?—That I will—I'll speak it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Oh, the devil!—Don't yawn so— (to OLD RAPID).

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: I never get a comfortable nap, never!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: You have a devlish good chance now—Con∣found all speeches — Oh!—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Pray be seated— (they sit on each side VORTEX) — Now we'll suppose that the chair— (pointing to a chair) —

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Suppose it the chair! why it is a chair, an't it?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Pshaw! I mean—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: He knows what you mean—'tis his humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh, he's witty!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, remarkably brilliant indeed!— (signifi∣cantly to his Father).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: What, you are a wit, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: A what? Yes, I am—I am a wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Well, now I'll begin.—Oh, what a delicious moment!—The House when they approve cry, "Hear him! hear him!" —I only give you a hint in case any thing should strike—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Push on.—I can never stand it— (aside).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Now I shall charm them— (addresses the chair). — "Sir, Had I met your eye at an earlier hour, I should not have blink'd the present question—but having caught what has fallen from the other side, I shall scout the idea of going over the usual ground." —What! no applause yet? (aside. —During this OLD RAPID has fallen asleep, and YOUNG RAPID, after shewing great fretfulness and impatience, runs to the back scene, throws up the window, and looks out). — "But I shall proceed, and, I trust, without interruption"— (turns round and sees OLD RAPID asleep).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Upon my soul this is—What do you mean, sir? —

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What's the matter?—Hear him! hear him!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Pray, sir, don't you blush — (sees YOUNG RAPID at the window). —What the devil!—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (looking round) Hear him! hear him!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: By the soul of Cicero, 'tis too much.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Oh, Neddy▪ for shame of yourself to fall asleep! —I mean to look out of the window—I am very sorry, sir, any thing should go across the grain.—I say, Ned, smooth him down!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I wil—What the devil shall I say?—The fact is, sir▪ I heard a cry of fire—upon—the—the—the water, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Well, well—But do you wish to hear the end of my speech?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Upon my honour, I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Then we'll only suppose this little interruption a message from the Lords, or something of that sort.— (They sit, YOUNG RAPID fretful.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Where did I leave off?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Oh! I recollect; at — "I therefore briefly con∣cluded with moving—an Adjournment"— (risng.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Nonsense! no such thing— (putting him down in the chair). —Oh I remember! "I shall therefore proceed, and, I trust, without interruption—"

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Dinner's on the table, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Get out of the room, you villain!—"Without interruption—"

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I say, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Hear him! hear him!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Dinner is waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (jumping up) Dinner waiting!—Come along, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Never mind the dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: But I like it smoking.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: So do I—Be it ever so little, let me have it hot.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Won't you hear my speech?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: To be sure we will—but now to dinner.—Come, we'll move together. Capital speech! Push on, sir. Come along, dad. Push him on, dad. Exeunt, forcing Vortex out.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III —An ancient Hall.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir HUBERT, leaning on CHARLES STANLEY.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Take comfort, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Where shall I find it, boy? To live on my estate, is ruin—to part with it, death My heart is twin'd round it. I've been the patriarch of my tribe—the scourge of the aggressor—the protector of the injur'd! Can I forego these dignities? My old grey-headed servants too, whose only remaining hope is to lay their bones near their lov'd master, how shall I part with them? I prate, boy, but 'tis the privi∣lege of these white hairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Oh! say on, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: All! all is dear to me! these warlike trophies of my ancestors! Charles, thou see'st that goodly oak, 'twas planted at my birth Would'st thou think it? In the late hurricane when the tempest humbled with the dust the proudest of the forest, it bravely met the driving blast—my people, with shouts of joy, haild the auspicious omen, and au∣gur'd from it prosperity to me and mine. Fondly I believ'd it—fondly I thought it. Fie! fie! I doat—

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: My Father, I doubt not but they augur'd truly. I must to the active world. Why should I fear that the virtue and independence you have inspird—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
