SP.P: Ah, boy! but while licentiousness and party zeal command the choicest gifts of fortune, virtue and genius must be content with their leavings.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant—delivers a Letter to Sir HUBERT, who reads it with great agitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ah! what i it shakes you, sir?—That letter!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Nothing, my dear boy!—'tis infirmity!—I shall soon be better.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Excuse me, dear sir (takes the letter, and reads.) "Mr. Vortex, at the request of Mr. Rapid, informs Sir H. Stanley, it is inconvenient to advance more money on mort∣gage. Mr. Vortex laments Sir Hubert's pecuniary embar∣rassments" —damnation"— "to relieve which, he will purchase the castle and estate." —Sooner shall its massy ruins crumble me to dust —Don't despond, my father: bear up!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: Oh, sir! At Neabob's table they have been so abusing your feyther!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And I've been fighting—

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Hush!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: What's his business?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Oh, sir! (concealing his agitation.) My friend Frank consults me on a love affair; and I must not betray his confidence —In his hurry he fell. Was'nt it so (significantly)?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees, sur, ees.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: You are not hurt, young man?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No, sur. Thank heaven, my head be a pure hard one.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Within. (Enter two Servants.) Attend my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: My boy, don't stay from me long.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Now, good Frank, ease my tortur'd mind.— What of my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
Why, your honour, Mr Bronze came laughing out of dining-room, and says, "Daame, how the old Baro∣net had been roasted." So, sur, I not knowing what they could mean by roasting a Christian, axed. "Why," say
he, grinning, "they voted, that it was a pity, the dignity of the bloody hand interfer'd, or the old beggar might set up a shop."

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: The old beggar might set up a shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Unmanner'd, cowardly babblers!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And that you sur, would make a dapper 'prentice.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I heed not that. But, when I forgive a father's wrongs—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: So says I, Domme, if young 'squire had been a∣mong them, he would have knocked all their heads together? Now wouldnt you, sur, have knock'd their heads together? Then they all laugh'd at me: which somehow made all the blood in my body come into my nuckles. So says I, "Mr. Bronze, suppose a case—suppose me young 'squire Stanley: now, say that again about his honour'd father." —So he did; and I lent him such a drive o'the feace. And I was knocking all their heads together pretty tightish, till the cook laid me flat wi the poker; then they all fell upon me; and when I could fight no longer, I fell a crying, and run to tell your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Thanks, my affectionate lad! Return to the Nabob's to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I be sartain I shall never do any good there.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: To-morrow you shall live with me. I shall dis∣miss all my servants—my circumstances require it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: What! all but me —What! I do all the work? —Lord, Lord, how glad I be, sur, you can't afford to keep any body but I.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Good Frank, farewell!—Hold—here (present∣ing a purse.)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: (refusing). Nay, prayee, sur, dan't you beheave unkind to me—I be a poor lad, that do worship and love you —not a spy for the lucre of gain—pray use me kindly, and don't gi' me a farding.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Frank. I beg your pardon.—Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Lord, how glad I be he can only afford to keep I. Ex.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Insult my father!—unmanly villain!—whoe'er thou art, thy life shall answer it! Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—Enter VORTEX, in great terror, reading a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P:
Dear me!—here's a terrible affair! (reads)
"Give me up the author of the slander on my father" — that was myself. I never can find in my heart to give myself up; "or personally answer the consequences; CHARLES STANLEY." Oh dear! since I find my words are taken down, I must be more parliamentary in my language. What shall I do? I can't fight; my poor head won't bear it; it might be the death of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (without). Huzza, my fine fellows! Bravo!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Eh! egad, a fine thought. Young Rapid is loaded muzzle high with Champaigne. I'll tell him he said the words, and make him own them. I've persuaded him into a marriage with my daughter: after that, the devil's in't if I can't persuade him into a duel.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Here I am tip-top spirits; ripe for any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: How did you like my Champaigne?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Oh! suits me exactly; a man is such a damn'd long while getting tipsy with other wine. Champaigne settles the business directly; it has made me—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Lively, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Lively! it has made me like a sky-rocket. Well, how did I behave? Quite easy wasn't I? Push'd on—at every thing—barr'd prosing. Jolly dogs within—the fat parson's a fine fellow—kept the bottle moving—said a nice short grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Well, and did you lose at play the five hundred pounds I ent you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: As easy as could be.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex▪
SP.P: That was lucky.
Very; particularly for those who won it—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Well, now youll do.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: Huzza! I'm a finish'd man [staggering, and strutting about]

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: You only want a quarrel to make you—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: A what? A quarrel. Damme, I'll settle that in two minutes (running off.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Stop. You need not go out of the room for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: What! will you quarrel with me, eh?—With all my heart

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Me! Oh no!—I say I could get you such fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: How, my dear fellow? Dash on.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Why, at dinner you reflected on the Baronet.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: No, it was you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: No, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Yes, it was you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Well, it might be I; but I don't say it was—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I do. Push on.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Young Stanley has demanded the author. Now, if you were to own the words—how the news-papers would teem with— "The elegant Charles Stanley was called out by the dashing Young Rapid about some trifle."

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Bravo!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Any thing does for a duel now a days. The length of a dancer's great toe; an election leg of mutton and trimmings.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Say no more. I'll do it. By heavens no man of fashion shall be more infamous—I mean more famous.— I'll go write to him directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: First take another bottle of Champaigne. You can't think what a free dashing style it will give you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I will [going—returns]. No, I can't take up this quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh dear! Why not? (alarmed.)

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Because I'm sure I'm depriving you of pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Vor.
SP.P: Oh, don't mind me! I give it you, to shew my re∣gard for you. Indeed, I've had so much fighting in my time, that with me it really ceases to be a pleasure; the sweetest things will cloy; so the quarrel's your's. I wash my hands of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: You're a damn'd good-hearted, generous fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Vor.
SP.P: Then you'll return triumphant, and marry my daugh∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: To be sure; keep moving (going) I hope he'll fight directly ike a sailor, I hate a calm, particularly when an enemy's in sight. Hold; what must we fight with? I can fence.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: You have no objection to pistols and bullets?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: I like bullets; they come so quick. But I must push on; the other botte, and then—I'm a first-rate felow —Champaigne for ever! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: You shall have my pistols—they've never been used (Enter Miss VORTEX) Here's policy. "Crown me, shadow me, with aurels." —Oh my dear, I've atchiev'd two such difficult points!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: How, my dear Nabob?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: In the first place, I've persuaded Young Rapid to marry you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Was that so difficult?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: No▪ no, certainly. But the next will delight you.—Rapid is going to have an affair of honour with Young Stanley.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: A duel! and about me!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Yes▪— (Aside) I may as well tell her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: Charming!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Now an't I a kind father, to set two young men fighting about you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Ah! that is, indeed, acting like a parent?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Egad, I must look after Rapid, though.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: But how did you manage it?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: By policy to be sure: for, as I observe in my speech— 'Policy is—"

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: And a very good observation it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: How do you know, till you hear it?—"Policy—"

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: But Pray go to Mr Rapid (pushing him off)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: "Poicy—'

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Nay, must insist— [Exit. VORTEX]. Oh delightful!—Oatland!
Enter JESSY. —Im in such uncommon spirits, Oatland!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: May inquire the cause madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: Certainly. A duel is going to be fought about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: A due —Horrible thought!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Sensibiity▪ I vow! Too comic, a vast deal! Ha! ha! cottage pathos must proceed from a source un∣know to me, Im sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: It proceeds, madam, from the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Umph!—Let me have no more of it (sharply)

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: I beg your pardon—I forgot the extent of a ser∣vant's duty▪—I forgot that servants have no right to feel pleasure or pain, but as their employers please; and that suppressing the sensibilities of Nature is consider'd in their wages (sarcastically).

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: No doubt of it.—That's so very sensibly ob∣serv'd, that I'll forgive you Oatland.—The pride of Young Stanley will be so humbled—

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Is the safety of that noble youth implicated?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P:
What —A lover, I suppose—came to the farm, I warrant—attended Miss Jessy in the dairy—ruffl'd
the cream with his sighs—talked of Arcadia, and sipped butter-milk —Ha! ha! I should not wonder, after what I've seen of his taste—Yes, he is implicated — I dare say Mr. Rapid will— (going).

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Heavens! Is Edward (catching hold of a chair for support).

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Edward!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: I mean, Madam, (trembling, and curtesying), is Mr. Rapids life involved?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: Upon my honour, you seem to have an uncom∣mon sensibility for all mankind!—Do you mean to sit down in my presence? Exit Miss VORTEX.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: No, madam! (sinks down in the chair.) Oh, Ed∣ward! unkind as thou art, how gladly would I resign my life, to save thee! (weeps).

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: In tears, Jessy? Sweet girl, tell me—

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Oh madam! the most dreadful event is about to take pace. Mr. Stanley is engaged in a duel with—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Forbid it, Heaven.—Let us fly to his Father: he may prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Alas, madam! I fear he regards not his father's injunctions.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Not regard his Father! Who, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Mr. Rapid, madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Mr. Rapid?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: Oh! (hiding her face)

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Is it so, sweet Jessy? But has he deserv'd thy love? Is he not unkind?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Oh! true, madam! But is not his life in danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: We will not lose a moment. Let us seek Sir Hub.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: I'm very faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: I'll support thee; for in addition to the oppression of our common grief, thou, sweet girl, must bear the ago∣nising weight of disappointed love. Come, rest on my arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: Oh, such kindness! I cannot speak—but indeed my heart feels it. Exeunt, ELLEN supporting JESSY.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Another Apartment in VORTEX'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter YOUNG RAPID, followed by FRANK, who carries Pis∣tols, a Sword, and Champaigne.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Got the pistols, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Here they be [lays them down]. Your Feather were axing for you sur.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: My father! Should any thing happen—when I reflect—Reflect? Zounds, that won't do. Some Cham∣paigne! (singing) "If a man can then die much bolder with brandy" (drinks). I'll write to him, however; a few words on a scrap of paper may cheer him (takes a letter out of his pocket, and is about to tear a piece of it off). What! reads "Dear Edward, your faithful Jessy Oatland" (strikes his head.) Jessy Oatand! What a scoundrel I am! kisses the letter.) Oh, Jessy, what an infernal pain at my heart!— More Champaigne!

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: A letter, sir, from Young Stanley.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Then the die is cast (Reads) "You are a scoun∣drel; meet me immediately, or," —Um, um, a decisive short letter enough. Damn this pain. Quick! my pistols! Take them to Stanley Park: there wait for me.—Oh, Jessy!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter OLD RAPID, at the back Scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ecod, he'll kill thee. I'll lay half-a-crown 'Squire Stanley hits thee the first shot.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: (coming forward.) Pistols—kill Stanley? Ned, tell me—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (aside). My father here. Oh, sir, nothing. Come, drink.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Look at me. Ah, that agitation! Tell me the cause! A parent commands you. Your old doating father intreats it!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (aside.) I must deceive him. Sir, I've receiv'd an insut, that no gentleman of fashion can submit to.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: Genteman of fashion!—Need a man resent it!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: Read that letter, and judge.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Lack-a-day! Consider you're only a taylor's son. [Reads.] "You're a scoundrel."—That's a hard word—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Would you have me submit to be called scoundrel?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: No, I wou'dn't— [with tears.] Yes, I wou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Sir, you don't feel like a man.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: I'm sure I feel like a father!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Read on, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: (reads.) 'And unless' (wipes the tears away) 'unless'—I can't—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: (takes the letter and reads.) "And unless you immediately give me the satisfaction of a gentleman, expect the chastisement due to a coward."

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Chastisement! Chastisement! Coward! (with irritation.) We are flesh and blood, Ned.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Woud you see me spurn'd?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: [emphatically, and running into his son's arms.] No!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Pray leave me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Where shall I go?—What shall I do?—What will become of me? Oh, boy, try to avoid it. Remem∣ber your od fater,—remember his life hangs on your's. But, Ned—don't forget you're a man!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Pray leave me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: I will. Farewell, my dear boy, 'twill break my old heart But remember you're a man, Ned.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: [alone.] So, Im proceeding full tilt to murder; have planted a dagger in a kind father's heart. But here goes (fills wine: throws away the bottle and glass.) Its power is gone. Oh! This infernal pain! Could I with honour avoid? (looking at the letter) Chastisement! Coward! Damnation! I must push on. Fool! Dolt! Villain that I am! Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III—A retired place in Stanley Park.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: What can it mean?—Charles parted from me in an agony the ingeniousness of his nature had not art to conceal;—he grasp'd my hand,—bade me farewell, as if it were for ever —then broke away—eaving me a prey to wid conjecture and despair;—soon shall I be at peace,—infirmity, when goaded on by sorrow, presses to the goal of life with doubed speed.—Sure'y thro' that laurel grove, I see two female figures gide along? my eyes are not of the best, and the sorrow I have felt for my dear boy has not strengthened them;—they approach.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Pardon, Sir Hubert, this intrusion. My name, sir is Ellen Vortex.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Madam, I welcome you as my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Oh, sir! the urgency of the moment will not al∣low me to thank such goodness as I ought; your son, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Ah! What of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: I saw him pass along—he fled from my outstretch'd arms—was deaf to my cries—e'en now he's engaged in a duel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Ha! (draws his sword and is running out, slag∣gers▪ drops his sword.—ELLEN and JESSY support him) My functions are suspended!—Oh nature! dost thou desert me at this moment?—Who is the viain that has caused it?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: Ah, my poor Edward!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Oh that I coud rush before my child, and re∣ceive the fatal ball in this old broken heart!—Perhaps— dreadful thought —e'en now the deadly tube is evelled at his manly breast (The report of a pistol is heard—ELLEN sinks into his arms.) Bear up I cannot support thee. (Ano∣ther pistol is discharged) —Horrible suspence!—what a death∣like silence!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Death▪—Oh, my adored Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Ah, my poor Edward!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: without. Huzza! huzza! (enters) Huzza!— He's safe—he's safe.—

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Who?—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: 'Squire Chares — Squire Charles,—Huzza!

DIV3.STAGE: (Exit —Sir H. folds his hands on his breast in silent gratitude.)

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Ah, my poor Edward!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Your son is safe;—heard you the words?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub
SP.P: They have shot life thro' me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen
SP.P: Jessy! rejoice with me. Seeing her dejected Wretch that I am, to forget thy sorrows!—Take comfort, sweet girl!—perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Tol de rol lol—Safe and sound—safe and sound— tol de rol lol.—

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Who?

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: My boy Neddy,—my darling Neddy, safe and sound,—tol de rol ol. Sees Sir HUBERT, and bows re∣spectfully. JESSY and ELLEN talk apart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: So, Mr. Rapid!—How happened this, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Really. Sir Hubert, I don't understand the cut of it; all I can say is▪ your son's behaviour was—oh— super-fine;— when they had fired their pistols—they drew out their swords▪ and your son disarmd Neddy, and then he generously gave him his sword again, which was extremely genteel.— for it was a brand new silver-hilted sword and, I suppose by the laws of honour, he might have kept it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Mr. Rapid, why did you break your appointment?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Mr. Vortex, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Mr. Vortex.—I fear your son has selected an im∣prudent preceptor.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Chose a bad pattern you think, sir?—I am afraid he has.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Will you, sir, favour me with a few minute's conversation?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: You know, Sir Hubert Im your faithful servant to command.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub
SP.P: (to Ellen.) Come, let us to our hero. Will you fair creature, condescend to be a crutch to an old man? (takes Ellen's arm.) I shall expect you▪ si.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Jessy!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: I follow, mada. (Exeunt Sir Hubert and Ellen.) Do address the father of Mr. Rapid?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: You do, pretty one!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: (taking his hand and kissing it.) I beg your pardon; but are you sure your son's life is safe— quite safe?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Yes —A very charming gir, I declare!—I'm very much oblig'd to you for taking notice of my Neddy!— Poor fellow! Nobody seemd to care what became of him.— Im very much oblig'd.—A sweet pretty-spoken creature as ever I saw! But I must away to the , or I shall be too late for the wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Wedding! whose, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Whose! why, my boy Neddy's with Miss Vor∣tex to be sure!
Married! Edward married! 'Tis too much— (leans on OLD RAPID for support.)

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Eh! what! speak —tell me!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy▪
SP.P: Oh, Edward! is this the return for my love? Have merited this cruel desertion?

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: Desertion!—What!—has the rasca—I shall choak myself—Has he behaved ill to so sweet a creature? Your tears tell me so.—I'll kill him.—Hes my own son, and I have a right to do it.—Your name, your name! pretty soul!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Jessy Oatland.—The indiscretion of my Father has made me a servant.

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P:
And the discretion of his Father has made him a gentleman—But 'll make the rasca know you are not humbled by your fathers conduct, nor is he exalted by his, a
villain!—Can he hope to be cal'd a man of honour for op∣posing his head to a pistol while himself levels the shaft of anguish at an innocent woman's heart!—But 'll kill him, thats one comfort.—Come with me, sweet one!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Sir, I must attend my mistress—I am servant to his bride— (weeps.)

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: I shall go mad!—Don't cry—If he by marriage, won't make you my daughter—I by adoption, wil —Good bye, sweet Jessy!—Oh, the rascal!—Cheer up!—The scoundrel▪—Pretty creature!—The dog! What a shape! —I'll kill him! Exeunt severally.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.—RAPID discovered, and Hair-dresser.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Dispatch! Why don't you dispatch?

SP.SPEAKER: H. D.
SP.P: Done in a moment sir,—pray keep your head still.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: (jumping up)▪ Oh, Jessy Oatand!—S'death— have not you done?

SP.SPEAKER: H. D.
SP.P: Sit down, sir—done in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Wel▪ well; Im as patient as— (Sits—Enter FRANK at the door RAPID jumps up and runs to him▪) — Well! speak—quick!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Sur——that is—se—no, I—went—?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: You tedious blockhead—s she gone? Is Jessy gone

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ees, sur.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: What! left her Father's!—Where is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I don't know—that is, I wont tell— (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: What must she think me? What I am—a rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: H. D.
SP.P: Sit down, sir;—done in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I am as calm as— [sits].
What do you want? (jumps up again.)

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, my master and Miss Vortex wait for you. Ex.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Aye, to fulfil that infernal marriage promise.—Oh, Jessy▪— to FRANK What are you at?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: Sur, I were only twiddleing about my thumbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: You are always twiddling about your thumbs. What shall I do? Go to them.—No, I'll write—I want to write.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Oh, you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: I tell you I want to write.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: I'm sure I don't hinder you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: S'death! then don't stand there.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: It be al the same to me where I stand moving to another place.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: Thickhead, bring pen and ink.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why did not you tell I so?

DIV3.STAGE: Exit, and returns with pens and ink.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Oh, this infernal pain? —A candle to seal a letter (Exit FRANK, and returns with a candle). —Zounds! it is not lighted!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.P: You didn't tell I to light it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Was ever man plagud with such a hollow-headed ninny hammer
(aside). May be that be better that a hollow-hearted one!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: (jumps up). Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My master has sent you those parchments to peruse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: throwing them down. I wouldn't read them for his estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: He wil wait on you, sir, directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: Begone all of you —Stop (to FRANK) Give me my coat FRANK helps him on with one arm —Bring the gass!— FRANK leaves him so, and brings down a dressing glass. —Leave me, dundrhead! Exit FRANK.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Bravo, my fine fellow! You fought nobly!—I say, who fird first?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Never mind, that's past!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Well now I must intrust you with a little secret — (they sit).

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: I have no objection to a little secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: In the first place, then, Ill read this paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: No; I'll read it—shall read it much quicker. (Reads) —"Receiv'd of Mr Vortex the sum of five thou∣sand pounds, in consideration of which I assign over all my right and title to hum um, um—Signed, ELLEN VOR∣TEX." I understand—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Now you must know the father of my niece—

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Jessy Oatland▪ (in reverie)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: No her name is Ellen.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: I know it I know it—I know it— (fretfully).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Her father died in India.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Wh all my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: With all your heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: Zounds! keep moving, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Yes if youll keep still.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: Then be quick

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Why I am quick an't I?—Died in India, and left her to my care. All was in—

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Confusion

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: You are right, al was in confusion. So I pre∣vail'd on —

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Jessy Oatland!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: No no, Elen—to sign that paper; since which, indeed, her affairs have urnd out pretty lucky. I pur∣chas'd this estate with her fortune, which will be your's, my boy —It was a very snug bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: What a horrible thing is the gift of speech!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Speech —Did you say any thing about a speech? Ah▪ had you heard mine out.—Do you remember how it began?— "Had I met your eye at an earlier hour, I should" —(During VORTEXS narration. RAPID, influenced by the most fretful impatience▪ has unconsciously bit, and torn to pieces, the paper given him by VORTEX.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: (jumping up) Sdeath and fire! Is this a time for speeches▪ Is not your daughter waiting?—Is not?—Oh, Jessy!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: True▪ another opportunity! But, oh! 'tis a pretty speech.—Well, now give me back the paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: The paper!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Yes, now you have thoroughly digested the con∣tents of the paper, give it me again.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Oh▪ the—the—the paper (sees it torn on the ground).

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Yes; that precious scrap that secures us a hundred thousand pounds, you dog!—Come, give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: My dear fellow! you gave me no paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: But I did, though.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: Yes, you certainly did; but then—you—you— did not—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: But I'll take my oath I did!—Come, give it me directly.— You— (sees the fragments on the ground). Eh! what!—No;—yes. I'm undone, I'm ruind. Oh, my head! I'm going, I'm going

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Upon my soul Im very sorry, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: But what?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: That infernal speech!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Oh! (looking at the scraps of paper) —Eh, but hold! when he marries my daughter he'll keep the secret for his own sake. Oh dear! I must lose no time.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: I'm very sorry; I'm sure if hearing your speech will be any compensation— (sits down) —

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: No, no, not now—come with me, all the law∣yers are waiting. Oh, pray come!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: I'm coming, but you're always in such a hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Ill send my daughter to him—I must push him. Pray come directly. Exit in a hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Upon my soul you'll break your neck, if you hurry. so. Am I always to have this infernal pain? (goes up to the glass). Behold a high-finished rascal at full length.— Curse me, if I can look myself in the face.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: (apart). There he stands!—Now, heart, be firm. Virtuous indignation, support me! Sir, my mistress waits for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Don't plague me about your mistress. Ill come by and by. Turns round Heaven and hell; Jessy Oatland!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: My mistress! sir, waits for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Your mistress!—A servant! Jessy Oatland a ser∣vant! A servant to—And I—Jessy!—my life!—my soul! —will you forgive—?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Wretch!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: I am.—I despise myself. On my knees, only listen to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Mr. Rapid!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: (jumping up). What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: How can you debase yourself—to—

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: How dare he debase me, madam, by offering to an honest heart the affections of a villain?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: (to Iessy) leave the room!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: (apart.) Now, poor heart! having pass'd thy pride's probation, retire to a corner, and break with weeping. Ex.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Sir! what am I to understand?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: That I'm crazy.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Have I deserv'd insult?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Upon my soul, I dont mean to insult you—I ask your pardon upon my knees. (kneels)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You, sur!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: (jumping up) What't the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Well, Ill forgive you, if you'll come directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: What do you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You bes a desperate villain! (Rapid going to strike.) Come, dan't you do that—it wont do. Poor sister, if you dad drawn a harrow across her heart, you could not have hurt her so.
Damn't—I know nothing of your sister! Who the devil is your sister? you—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, Jessy Oatland!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: What! your sister—the brother of Jessy my servant? Damnation? why did not you tell me so? To raise my hand against the brother of Jessy? I shal go mad! Frank will you forgive me? I love Jessy—by my soul I do! And may heaven desert me, if— (kneels)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Heyday!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: (jumping up) What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: (to Frank) Leave the room! (Exit Frank.) — Insult upon insult! What satisfaction—

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: I know what you want. Come along; Ill fight you directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Fight! Nonsense.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Then I'll ask your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: But what the devils the meaning of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Why, don't you see I'm mad—stark staring mad!

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: Mr. Rapid!

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: (jumping round) What do you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: Oh, Lord how fierce Stanley looks at me. Pray come, Mr. Rapid. (To Stanley) Sir, your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: That little fellow will break his neck to a certainty.

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: I have just seen a lovely girl that you have wrong'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: I know I have; and I'll fight you again, if you like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley
SP.P: Could the result benefit Jessy Oatland, I would accept your invitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: The fact is, I am the most unhappy—the—What do you charge for shooting a man? Ill give you a thousand to blow my brains out. Im the most miserable dog.—Pray, sir, will you tell me one thing? Are you a man of fashion?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: trust Im a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: That's pretty much the same thing—an't it, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: It ought to be

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Pray sir, how did you become a gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley
SP.P: imply, by never committing an action that would not bear reflection

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Can I be a gentleman and an honest man?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley
SP.P: Can you be a gentleman, and not an honest man?

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: Pray, sir, have you always an inferna pain at your heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: No—Huzza! Thank you. By heav'n I'll— Now don't hurry yourself.—If I dont, may I— walks about.

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: Ah Mr Rapid, how different are our situations! You possessing the love of a most charming and fascinating girl dash the cup of happiness away.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: May be not, my dear fellow Push on.

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: I, possessing the heart of my dear Ellen, am mi∣serable; because, on account of the narrowness of her for∣tune she compels me to abandon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap.
SP.P: What The narrowness of her fortune compels—

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: Yes, I say—
No! Don't say it again. Dont despair, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley
SP.P: She has given a fata paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Rap
SP.P: A paper! Yes, I know I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Stanley.
SP.P: And I'm come to take eave of her.

No, you are not—Ill show you such a scene—Nay, don't ask me any questions; follow me, thats al. Wait at the door; and when I cry, Hem come in But dont be in such a hurry. By heavens, the pain in my side is better already; Huzza Come along. [Going returns and runs to the glass, and nods.] How do you do? How do you do? What! you rascal! you can grin again can you? Come along; but dont hurry; because my dear fellow! 'tis im∣possible
to do any thing well in a hurry Come along! but zounds! never hurry. Exeunt, RAPID speaking very quick.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.—Another Apartment in VORTEX's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: How beest thee now, Jessy?

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Better. Quite recoverd. What pass'd between you and Edward?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, at first, he were in a desperate passion; but when told him I were thy brother, he were so humble, and did ax I so to forgive un, that I could say no more to un. Dom it, I could not hit him, when he were down; and Ive a notion his conscience was pegging him about pretty tightish. He swear'd he did love thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Did he, Frank? Did he say he lov'd me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: What! torn the paper!—A hot-headed—only wait till he's my husband—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Egad, I wish he would come, tho'—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Oh! here he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: How my poor frame trembles!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: I vow I feel uncommon discompos'd—Oat∣land! your arm, child! leans on JESSY)

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Heavens, how interesting! the languor of those lovey eyes—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Flattering creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: My senses are restor'd. Oh, will you pardon— will you again receive a heart ful of love and adoration?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: What shall I do?— must pardon him. (Miss VORTEX is preparing to speak)

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
Y. Rap▪
SP.P:
Detestable?—But I'm pardon'd, your eyes tell me so. Thanks, my angel! (running to her and kneeling.)
I'm so oppress'd with joy▪—Ma'am, will you have the good∣ness to help me up?—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Help you up▪—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: He! he'l he Gi me a buss, Jessy! he! he! thee bes a domnd honest fellow (shaking RAPIDs hand) I'll run and tell poor Feyther.—Now I shall have a farm of my own! (capering and snapping his fingers.) —Dong it, how I will work —He! he▪ he! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: To be us'd so twice in one day!—it is not to be borne.—Nabob! wont you fight him?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: No, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: Coward!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Youd better be quiet, or I'll convince you I'm none, however.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor.
SP.P: He! he! I declare it is so uncommon ridicu∣lous!—so comic!—He! he!—Im quite faint with laugh∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: Shall I assist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vor
SP.P: No. (resentfully.) I must retire, or I shall ex∣pire with laughing.—he! he!—Oh!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Heaven! what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: Alow me to introduce Mrs Rapid, madam.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen
SP.P: Sweet Jessy —Sir, I thank you for giving my heart a pleasurable sensation, which I thought it had for ever taken leave of.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Bless your heart! perhaps I may tickle it up a little more.— (To VORTEX) Now, stand out of the way, wil you?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: You're quite free and easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: My way.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: You forget 'tis my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: No, I don't;—you bought it with her money, you know.—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Umph!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Mum, now for young Stanley's cue. (To EL∣LEN) Pon my honour ma'am, any man might be proud to —Hem He doesnt hear me—Such beauty!—such a shape! —such a—Hem—

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Zounds! he's here again (getting behind YOUNG RAPID) What does he want?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Shall ask him?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Do. Ill be very much obliged to you

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I will.—Ill manage (winking and nodding to VORTEX)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh, thank you!
Once more, my Elen! supported by an indulgent parent's bessing on our union, I entreat—

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen
SP.P: Oh Chares! shal then return your father's good∣ness by destroying his hopes for ever? Shall I repay my Stan∣leys love by inflicting on him penury and sorrow? In pity, no more!

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap
SP.P: (to CHARLES STANLEY). What may be your business here sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: came to take leave.—

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: Hush (apart). —To inquire respecting that ladys fortune. We'l soon answer all that, wont we? [nod∣ding to VORTEX.]

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I say, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap
SP.P: [stopping him.] We grant it,—we grant Mr. Vortex has recover'd property to a considerable amount, but what signifies that? She assigned it for five thousand pounds! —You see how Im going on (to Nabob.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh, thank you, my dear friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I've seen the paper; havent I?— [to Vortex.]

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: And I shou'd be satisfied —

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: You woud be satisfied if you saw it.—Certainly —very proper—nothing in nature can be more reasonable; so Nabob shew him the paper, and settle the business at once (walks about, VORTEX following him) Shew him the paper —dont keep the gentleman waiting al day.—Shew him the paper. My dear fellow whats the use of walking after me? Shew him the paper.
SP.STAGE: Vortex taking advantage of the pauses in the foregoing speech.
SP.P: I say my dear friend hush! Be quiet! I want to speak to you; you forget you destroyed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I destroyed it!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Hush!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: He says I destroyed it!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: I did not▪ —Ill take my oath I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: And it is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles and Ellen.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: True, upon my honour! He has no more hold on your estates, mad, than I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles
SP.P: [kneeling to ELLEN.] Will you now allow the humble Stanley to destroy the hopes of wealthy Ellen? Will you permit me to repay your love with penury and sorrow?

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: Oh, chide on! [raising him.] Dear Stanley, my happiness is now complete.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: This is your house, ma'am.—I give you joy!— Sir, I give you joy!—Nabob I give you joy!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Oh, my head! You villian!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Don't talk about villany,—it will make you worse. Sit down, my dear felow!

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: He's justly punished for the falsehood of the story he told—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I say, he's justly punished for the length of the story he told.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Mr. Rapid, in expressing my obligtions, allow me to be—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Not more than a minute, I entreat.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub.
SP.P: Be patient.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap
SP.P: I won't.—Let me come at him.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter OLD RAPID and SIR HUBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy
SP.P: [YOUNG RAPID and JESSY kneel.] Your blessing, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: What? Oh! falls own on his knees, and em∣braces them both

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Hub
SP.P: (after talking apart to his son.) Mr. Rapid▪ by asserting your character as a man of honour, in rewarding the affections of this amiabe woman, you command my praise; for bestowing happiness on my dear Charles, receive an old man's bessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: Approbation from Sir Hubert Stanley is praise indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Dam me▪ there's the son of a taylor for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: What, a taylor!

SP.SPEAKER: O Rap.
SP.P: Yes; and let me tell you that one guinea ho∣nestly gotten by blood drawn from the finger, is sweeter than a million obtained, by blood drawn from the heart!—so take that.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap
SP.P: Well, Nabob, how do you feel?

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Egad tis very odd;—but I declare I feel light and comfortable since Ellen has got her Estate▪ and I some∣how breathe more free▪ I've a notion the last line of my speech is true
Come, I'l hear the last line.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex.
SP.P: Why, "that the first step towards securing the esteem of others, is to secure your own."

SP.SPEAKER: Y Rap.
SP.P: Stick to the last line.

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: And, dear uncle take Sir Hubert Stanley for your Physician Follow his prescuption of justice and bene∣voence, and my life on it, you will soon thank me for my recommendation.

SP.SPEAKER: Vortex
SP.P: We, to show the sincerity of my intentions, al∣low me, Ellen, to present you these parchments, the title-deeds of this Estate (present parchments).

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: I say, Ned, what nice measures they would make!

SP.SPEAKER: Ellen.
SP.P: And Sir▪ allow me to shew you the true value of riches— (giving parchments to Staney)▪ Convert them into happiness

SP.SPEAKER: O. Rap.
SP.P: Well, I've only one observation to make.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I hope it is a short one.

SP.SPEAKER: Iessy.
SP.P: What, impatient again?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Rap.
SP.P: I am, and if I err,
SP.L: 'Tis you my gen'rous Patrons, are the cause,
My heart's impatient for your kind applause.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: WRITTEN BY M. P. ANDREWS, Esq. M. P. Spoken by Mrs. MATTOCKS.
DIV1.L: SHAKESPEARE, a shrewd old quiz, in his dull age,
Said, very gravely, "All the worlds a stage."
But if the Poet on our times could drop,
He d rather own that "all the world's a shop."
"And what's the trade?" exclaim the critic railers,
Why, "Men and women all are merely taylors."
Nay. frown not, Beaux; and Ladies, do not pout;
You've all your cuttings in and cuttings out.
And, first, Miss Hoyden, just escap'd from school,
Slighting mamma, and all domestic rule;
If she on fashion's road should chance to trip,
What says the world? why, "Miss has made a slip."
And if, a falling character to save,
She weds with age just tottring oer the grave,
The sportive world will still enjoy the joke,
And spouse, at home, at once is made a cloke.
The Politician too who, when in place,
Views public measures with a smiling face,
Croaks▪ when he's out, a discontented note,—
Sure he's a taylor—he has turnd his coat.
Oft have I measur'd you when closely sitting,
To see what twist, what shape, what air was fitting.
Once more I'll try, if youll make no resistance;
Mines a quick eye, and measures at a distance.
[Produces the shrs and measure.
Great Mr. Alderman—your worship—sr,
If you can stomach it, you need not stir.
Room you require, for turtle and for haunch,
'Tis done—two yards three quarters round the paun
Slim sir, hold up your arm—Oh, you're a poet,
You want a coat, indeed—your elbows show it.
Don't tremble man: there's now no cause for fears;
Though oft you shirk the Gemmen of the sheers;
Genius stands still, when taylors interpose;
'Tis like a watch—it ticks—and then it goes.
The needle dropt, the warlike sword I draw,
For oft our Sex must yield to martial law;
Lady Hubbuffet came to me last night,
"Oh, my dear ma'am, I'm in such a fright;
"They've drawn me for a man; and, what is worse,
"I am to soldier it, and mount a horse:
"Must wear the breeches" Says I "Don't deplore,
"What in your husbands life you always wore;
"But that your La'ship's heart may cease from throbbing,
"Let your fat Coachman mount upon fat Dobbin;
"And for the good old pair I'll boldly say,
"Nor man, nor horse, will ever run away."
"Run!'—"Arrab, who is that dare fear betray?"
(Cries patriot Paddy, hot from Bantry Bay.) [with a Broge.
"The Frenchmen came, expecting us to meet 'em,
"And sure we all were ready there to greet 'em,
"With piping hot potatoes made of lead,
"And powder that would save instead of bread;
"And, by my soul, such dainty fine fat frogs,
"With warm dry lodging for them in the bogs."
"They came, alas!' cried I▪ of terror full,
"They made a "conquest?" No, they made a bull."
But softly—what with measures, bulls, and battle,
You must be tird with my poor foolish prattle;
But while you look so pleasant, kind, and clever,
Had I my way, I'd talk to you for ever.
